awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Examining the Performance of Historic Masonry Structures after the December 2021 Midwest Tornadoes
awd_abstract_narration:
On December 10-11, 2021, the “Quad-State” tornadoes damaged structures across Kentucky, Arkansas, Missouri, and Tennessee. This Grant for Rapid Response Research (RAPID) will conduct a four-day field survey to document damaged and undamaged masonry structures from this event in Mayfield, Kentucky, with the goal to provide new knowledge and data about the performance of masonry structures during tornadic loading. Many historic masonry structures are presently excluded in recent versions of tornadic building code requirements. The detailed textual and image data collected during this research will contribute to understanding the relationship between masonry construction types and building damage during tornadoes, can help communities to better prepare for and be resilient from natural hazard events, and can inform future building code requirements. Data collected from this award will be archived in the National Science Foundation (NSF)-supported Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Data Depot (https://www.DesignSafe-CI.org).  This award will contribute to the NSF role in the National Windstorm Impact Reduction Program (NWIRP). 

The focus of this research is 1) to evaluate the efficacy of retrofit and adaptively reused masonry structures, 2) to elucidate potential weaknesses in other historic structures across the United States, and 3) to identify resilient masonry connection typologies for future retrofits and additions. This research will provide new knowledge and data concerning certain types of masonry structures (Risk Categories 1 and 2) during tornadic loading. This knowledge can lead to improving the performance of historic masonry structures, as many historic masonry structures are not addressed in recent additions to tornadic building design criteria (American Society of Civil Engineers 7-22, Minimum Design Loads and Associated Criteria for Buildings and Other Structures). The field reconnaissance will generate a unique data set that will include ground-based and drone-based photos and ground-based detailed structural surveys focusing specifically on connection typologies due to retrofitting or building additions.  Data will be collected using field equipment from the NSF-supported NHERI Reconnaissance (RAPID) Facility at the University of Washington. The merit of this work lies in the detailed data set generated, which will encompass 3D point cloud models, images, and architectural drawings for 50 masonry structures. This more detailed data set will help quantify the efficacy of different retrofitting and strengthening methods to inform future solutions and building code requirements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This RAPID project examined the performance of historic masonry structures in Mayfield, Kentucky, following the devastating Quad State Tornadoes that hit the region in December 2021. The research aimed to provide new knowledge about how historic masonry buildings (specifically Risk Category 1 and 2) respond to tornadic loading. This is important as these categories are currently excluded from recent tornado design guidelines (ASCE 7-22). The project had three main objectives: 1) conduct post-event surveys of historic structures in Mayfield, KY; 2) create aerial photogrammetry models of the damaged buildings; and 3) analyze the collected data to relate damage to construction techniques and retrofitting solutions.   

Key outcomes and findings from this project included in-person surveys and aerial photography documentation for all historic structures in Mayfield; this was complemented with 3D photogrammetry models of the damaged buildings. Statistical analysis of the collected data revealed relationships between observed damage and specific building characteristics such as the year structures were built, their architectural style, and their current function; this analysis enhanced our understanding of factors that make buildings more vulnerable to tornado damage. The project also conducted a structural analysis that compared traditional code-based approaches with higher fidelity point cloud-based simulations, highlighting the differences in approximate methods versus in-the-field reality.   

The research produced several peer-reviewed publications in journals such as the Journal of Cultural Heritage, the Journal of Structural Engineering, and Engineering Failure Analysis; the data and models have been made freely available to other researchers through the NHERI DesignSafe-CI Data Portal. Beyond the technical outcomes, this project provided training opportunities for students at multiple levels: 1) ten undergraduate students participated as REUs, gaining hands-on research experience, 2) the data was incorporated into undergraduate and graduate courses, exposing students to real-world disaster response applications, 3) a PhD student completed their dissertation based on this work.   

Regarding intellectual merit, the project advanced understanding of historic masonry structures' performance under extreme wind loads. By conducting surveys and creating high-fidelity 3D models, the research team was able to identify failure modes and important parameters for structural resilience. The project also developed novel methodologies for integrating field reconnaissance data with advanced computational modeling techniques. These findings contribute to the fundamental knowledge base for structural engineering and historic preservation fields, potentially informing future updates to building codes and retrofit strategies.  

In terms of broader impacts, the project outcomes can help protect valuable architectural assets from future natural disasters. Furthermore, by making all data and models publicly available, the project promotes open science and enables further research by the broader scientific community. Ultimately, this research contributes to creating more sustainable and resilient urban infrastructure, with engineering and cultural heritage benefits extending beyond the immediate study area. The work also provided significant educational benefits, engaging undergraduate and graduate students in hands-on research experiences and incorporating real-world data into engineering curricula. This exposure to disaster response applications helps prepare the next generation of engineers to address complex societal challenges.   

 


Last Modified: 03/03/2025
Modified by: Rebecca Napolitano

This RAPID project examined the performance of historic masonry structures in Mayfield, Kentucky, following the devastating Quad State Tornadoes that hit the region in December 2021. The research aimed to provide new knowledge about how historic masonry buildings (specifically Risk Category 1 and 2) respond to tornadic loading. Statistical analysis of the collected data revealed relationships between observed damage and specific building characteristics such as the year structures were built, their architectural style, and their current function; this analysis enhanced our understanding of factors that make buildings more vulnerable to tornado damage. In terms of broader impacts, the project outcomes can help protect valuable architectural assets from future natural disasters.
